While I was starting a thread in creation vs. evolution, I went to reach for my bible, specifically to the book of Genesis. Then I decided I would rather talk about a different type of Genesis. There was a Simulation Tool developed out of Caltech that has been used to model Nueral Networks. Its name is Genesis. The purpose of this project is to use the principle of  multiple realizability, "the contention that a given mental kind (property, state, event) is realized by distinct physical kinds", can be employed using computers to accurately model the nueral and biological mechanisms of the brain. This is being done in order to obtain greater understanding into the workings of the "mind".
 
 Of course, the question that arises from such research gets back to the old idea of the  Turing Test. This idea was formulated by Alan Turing in the 1950's when he postulated that one day machines could be programmed with intelligence rivaling man's. The Turing Test was based on the ability of the computer to simulate human conversation. Turing thought, if you could have a person sit and talk to a computer and not be able to tell they were not talking to a machine, the computer could be said to have acquired intelligence.
 
 It is easy to see how this kind of indicator would fail to gauge the intelligence of the machine. First, Turing stated that the machine only had to simulate conversation, not actually engage in it. Second, the machine's intelligence is limited by the ingenuity of the programmer, as it is a dependent system. Finally, it is fully possible to generating outputs of characters or sounds without knowledge of what those patterns represent. Even though Turing's Test remains flawed, he was the originator the Artificial Intelligence idea, and attempted to formulate criteria to determine when this had been achieved.
 
 In light of advances in biological and quatum computing, nanotechnology, fuzzy logic, and nueral networks, the prospect of AI is as real as it has ever been. Therefore, it will remain one of the hotly debated areas in the science and philosophical arenas. This is why I have dedicated a thread to its discussion. Your thoughts, comments, and reservations about this new and exciting field are welcome. It is interesting to note that the term Genesis is often used in science and science fiction. Perhaps scientists are open to the idea of a creator, especially as they are increasingly finding themselves in that position.

 Well, let me give you an extremely brief overview. There is a big portion of every brain of animals with visual sensory mechanisms that is devoted to processing visual stimuli. Vision is generally assumed to be most the complicated modality because its dimension and resolution are higher than any other modality. This means that understanding (human or biologically derived) visual processing mechanisms up to the level of visual consciousness is probably the hardest problem to tackle in neuroscience. It also means that solving it will give tools and patterns to solve other processing mechanisms.
 Obviously, the exact details of the visual pathway from stimulus to consciousness is very much unknown. From anatomical and physiological and related works, the general outline of the pathway has been that: information gets sampled at the retina, trasferred to the thalamus (something called the lateral geniculate nucleus), and then to cortial processing areas (in the posterior and temporal regions of the brain). 
 
 In a computational framework, the first stage in this processing (generally referred to as early vision) does extraction and coding of information required for higher processing. Consciousness DOES NOT appear in early vision. Physiologically and anatomically speaking, I think people have more or less accepted that processing units up to the thalamus do not contribute directly to consciousness. There are still debates as to which visual cortical areas may be directly involved in consciousness.
 
 As for the details of the work, the researchers recorded spiking activities for a lot of cells in the thalamus, bin the spikes to get a bunch of signals over time, and this signal over time is what they used. In the first part of the experiment, they present a bunch of stimuli, record activities, ASSUME all processing up to the thalamus can be represented by a linear system, and calculate the impulse response of the linear system (almost like a calibration process). In the second part of the experiment, they present a bunch of stimuli, record activities, and use the inverted impulse response to recover the stimuli. Exact details of information coding up to the thalamus is still not clear, so if you have seen the original papers, you'll see that it's really crappy work. Anyone can use least square to find the closest linear impulse response function to a system.
